The case of Jeanette
Jeanette is a 50-year-old woman with widespread

outpatient, she is admitted to hospital when her

when resting or performing only minimal move-
ments. Radiotherapy has given her some relief from
her symptoms, but this was short-lived; she is now

Jeanette explains to her doctor, Dr Hearn, that noth-

tackle her pain, they do help her to go to sleep.
After consultation with his colleagues on the
ward and on the oncology team, Dr Hearn concludes
that Jeanette has very few treatment options remain-
ing. She is now very frail and seriously unwell, and
Dr Hearn believes that she has only days left to live.
He approaches an anaesthetist at the hospital in the
hope that she might be able to administer spinal
analgesics, which could provide Jeanette with pain
relief through a line inserted at the base of her spine.
The anaesthetist, Dr Robertson, is unwilling to per-
form the procedure, since she is concerned about the
–
bed sores that Jeanette has at the base of her back
inserting the line could expose Jeanette to the risk of
serious infection.

Dr Hearn is disappointed with the anaesthetist s
decision, since he feels that, even if there is a risk of
ff
infection, it is more harmful to leave her su ering
fi
and in pain throughout her nal days. He explains to
Jeanette that the only remaining option is to try
increasing her analgesics again, which she agrees to.
Unfortunately, as is sometimes the case, the opioids

cause her to su er from distressing hallucinations and

data.vignette: A 50-year-old woman with metastatic renal cancer and painful bony disease is admitted for worsening symptoms. She has constant pain at rest. Prior radiotherapy gave only brief relief. Escalating opioids has not controlled her pain and has caused distressing hallucinations and confusion, so doses were reduced. She is now frail and appears to be nearing the end of life. An anesthetist declines a neuraxial analgesic catheter because she has sacral pressure ulcers and the insertion site could seed a serious infection. The patient says she cannot tolerate being awake in pain and asks to be kept asleep until she dies. Her family wants to remain able to talk with her and worries that deep sedation could shorten her life, but they also do not want her to suffer. Hospital policy and state law allow either approach in this situation. A decision is needed tonight as her agitation and pain are escalating.
data.choice_1: Start continuous deep palliative sedation and focus on comfort-only care
data.choice_2: Avoid continuous deep sedation and continue symptom control while keeping her awake

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: The vignette currently leans toward deep sedation as the clinically inevitable next step (e.g., 'opioids not controlled her pain', 'now frail and appears to be nearing the end of life', 'cannot tolerate being awake in pain'). This makes the alternative feel clinically inadequate rather than ethically different. Rebalance by clarifying that other reasonable, non-sedating options remain but have tradeoffs. Edits: (1) Replace 'escalating opioids has not controlled her pain' with 'opioid escalation has provided incomplete relief and caused hallucinations/confusion limiting further titration'. (2) Add that interventional pain service feels a trial of ketamine/lidocaine infusion, nerve block, or rapid re-irradiation consult could reduce pain but may take time and have side effects. (3) Rephrase 'appears to be nearing the end of life' to a neutral statement like 'advanced disease with limited prognosis' without implying imminent death unless necessary. (4) Avoid language implying that being awake necessarily equals severe suffering; specify that the goal would be proportional, intermittent sedation and other adjuvants to keep her interactive if possible.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Choice 2 is vague and not an actionable order; it risks being interpreted as 'do nothing' or 'undertreat pain'. Make the alternatives mutually exclusive and clinically concrete. Suggested rewrite: Choice 1: 'Initiate continuous deep palliative sedation (e.g., midazolam infusion titrated to unresponsiveness) with comfort-focused goals; document DNR/allow natural death and stop non-comfort interventions.' Choice 2: 'Pursue proportional symptom management without continuous deep sedation: optimize multimodal analgesia (opioid rotation + antipsychotic for hallucinations, adjuvants such as ketamine), consider intermittent/light sedation only, and reassess for feasible procedural options; maintain ability to interact.' Ensure Choice 2 explicitly states a ceiling (no continuous deep sedation).

key_information.suggested_changes: Some details are either missing for ethical stakes or could be tightened. Add: (1) Confirm decision-making capacity (is she delirious from pain/meds?); if fluctuating, state she is currently lucid enough to consent or that capacity is borderline and reassessment is underway—this is key to the ethics. (2) Clarify code status and whether she has an advance directive/previous statements about consciousness at end of life. (3) Specify what 'policy and state law allow either approach' refers to (palliative sedation is permitted when symptoms are refractory and intent is symptom relief) without legalese. Remove/condense: (a) 'constant pain at rest' duplicates 'cannot tolerate being awake in pain'—keep one. (b) 'an anesthetist declines...' could be shortened to 'neuraxial catheter deemed too high infection risk due to sacral ulcers'.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, deep continuous sedation is framed as the only humane option, making Choice 2 feel like avoidable suffering. Increase genuine equipoise by making Choice 2 a robust, ethically costly plan rather than undertreatment. Add that: (1) pain is severe but potentially partially controllable with aggressive multimodal therapy and/or intermittent sedation; (2) deep continuous sedation would likely eliminate meaningful interaction and may necessitate stopping oral intake, which the family/patient value differently; (3) patient’s expressed preference is strong but could be influenced by acute distress—clinicians worry about irreversible loss of communication if sedation started. Also specify that both choices meet accepted palliative practice standards in this hospital when properly documented, to prevent one seeming nonstandard.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Tighten Choice 2 so graders don’t disagree about what it entails. Specify a concrete, clinically plausible alternative plan (e.g., proportional/episodic sedation only, rotation to different opioid + antipsychotic for hallucinations, ketamine infusion, methadone, regional block that avoids ulcer area, or transfer to ICU/anesthesia for monitored analgesia). Clarify that the team can likely reduce suffering while preserving interaction, but not eliminate it, so the tradeoff is clear.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 reads like leaving the patient in severe uncontrolled pain after options have failed, making Choice 1 the obvious ethical answer. Rebalance by (1) adding remaining symptom-management options that are reasonably expected to improve comfort while keeping some wakefulness (opioid rotation with delirium management, ketamine/lidocaine, carefully titrated midazolam for intermittent respite, etc.), and (2) adding a morally serious cost to Choice 1 beyond family preference—e.g., the patient has periods of lucidity and previously valued being able to speak with family/complete urgent personal matters, or there is uncertainty about imminence of death so prolonged deep sedation could foreclose meaningful time. Ensure each option has a clear benefit and a clear ethical cost.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove language that steers toward deep sedation (e.g., “cannot tolerate being awake in pain,” “kept asleep until she dies,” “distressing hallucinations”). Rephrase neutrally: “reports pain despite opioids; developed neurocognitive adverse effects.” Replace “appears to be nearing the end of life” with a clinically grounded estimate (e.g., “palliative team estimates prognosis of days to short weeks”). Avoid implying one choice is more compassionate.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use clinician-facing terminology and structure: specify current analgesic regimen class and adverse effects (opioid-induced neurotoxicity/delirium), document capacity/mental status, and clarify consult services (palliative care/anesthesia). Replace “kept asleep until she dies” with “continuous deep sedation until death (CDSUD)” or “continuous palliative sedation.” Clarify why neuraxial is contraindicated (local infection/ulceration near sacral region; bacteremia risk) and whether alternative regional blocks were considered.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the clinical picture: distinguish pain vs agitation/delirium; state whether confusion is ongoing after opioid reduction, and whether she currently has decision-making capacity. Remove redundant phrases (e.g., “constant pain at rest”). Add a sentence establishing that other reversible causes and proportional sedation trials were attempted or are unavailable tonight. Ensure the forcing mechanism is one clear sentence (e.g., “Overnight staffing limits options; decision required before escalating sedation/transfer”).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both options parallel, concrete, and ~10–15 words without extra framing. For example:
- Choice 1: “Initiate continuous deep palliative sedation with comfort-focused goals of care.”
- Choice 2: “Use proportional, intermittent sedation and analgesia while preserving wakefulness.”
Avoid vague phrasing like “continue symptom control,” and avoid “avoid” as the lead verb.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Re-balance the clinical facts so Choice 2 is not framed as knowingly leaving her in uncontrolled, refractory suffering. For example: (1) state that with a carefully titrated regimen (e.g., lower-dose opioid rotation plus adjuvant) she can be comfortable enough to converse but has intermittent breakthrough pain/agitation; (2) clarify prognosis uncertainty (could be days vs a few weeks) so continuous deep sedation would forfeit potentially meaningful time; (3) rephrase Choice 2 to a positively framed, ethically defensible goal (e.g., “use proportional/intermittent sedation and analgesia aimed at keeping her interactive when possible, accepting some risk of ongoing distress”).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close the obvious middle-ground options. Either: (A) explicitly rule out proportional/intermittent sedation, ketamine/lidocaine infusions, nerve blocks, transfer to ICU/hospice, and rapid palliative consult as unavailable/contraindicated tonight; OR (B) redefine the binary to compare two realistic comprehensive strategies: Choice 1 = “continuous deep sedation until death starting tonight,” Choice 2 = “proportional/intermittent palliative sedation with a ceiling (no continuous deep sedation), prioritizing wakeful interaction,” making clear the team must choose one protocol now (order sets are mutually exclusive, staffing/monitoring constraints).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Add details showing why standard palliative-sedation guidance does not clearly settle the case. For example: document that her symptom refractoriness is contested (some analgesic options exist but would require monitoring/resources not available overnight), that her expected survival is uncertain (not clearly imminent death), and that institutional policy offers two sanctioned pathways with no hierarchy. Also remove/soften any wording implying she is definitively ‘refractory’ or ‘actively dying’ unless you simultaneously justify why guidelines still leave room for clinician judgment.

data.vignette: A 50-year-old woman with metastatic renal cancer and painful bone disease is admitted for uncontrolled pain and episodic agitation. Opioid escalation has provided incomplete relief and triggered delirium and hallucinations, limiting further titration. After dose reduction and treatment of reversible causes, she is intermittently lucid and can still converse. The palliative team estimates a limited prognosis but cannot say whether it is days or a few weeks. A neuraxial analgesic catheter is judged too high risk because sacral pressure ulcers could seed infection. Overnight staffing cannot support a monitored ketamine or lidocaine infusion, and transfer is not feasible until morning. Hospital policy and state law permit either continuous palliative sedation or a proportional approach when documented for symptom relief. Tonight she asks for continuous deep sedation until death. Her family asks to keep her awake enough to talk and finish personal goodbyes. You must enter one of two mutually exclusive sedation protocols tonight.
data.choice_1: Initiate continuous deep palliative sedation with comfort-focused goals of care.
data.choice_2: Use proportional, intermittent sedation and multimodal analgesia while preserving interaction when possible.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating that during a lucid interval she is assessed to have decision-making capacity, understands that deep sedation will likely prevent further interaction, and nonetheless explicitly refuses proportional/intermittent sedation.

Add a clause stating whether proportional/intermittent sedation is expected to provide inadequate relief overnight (e.g., “despite adjuncts, she is likely to remain in severe pain/agitation unless continuously deeply sedated”).

Add a clause stating continuous deep sedation tonight carries a significant near-term risk of respiratory depression/aspiration (and possible life-shortening) given her uncertain prognosis, while proportional sedation is expected to control symptoms adequately but may allow breakthrough suffering.

data.vignette: A 50-year-old woman with metastatic renal cancer and painful bone disease is admitted for uncontrolled pain and episodic agitation. Opioid escalation has provided incomplete relief and triggered delirium and hallucinations, limiting further titration. After dose reduction and treatment of reversible causes, she has lucid intervals. During one tonight, she is assessed to have decision-making capacity and understands that continuous deep sedation will likely prevent further interaction. The palliative team estimates a limited prognosis but cannot say if it is days or a few weeks. A neuraxial analgesic catheter is too high risk because sacral pressure ulcers could seed infection. Overnight staffing cannot support a monitored ketamine or lidocaine infusion. Transfer is not feasible until morning. Despite adjuncts and intermittent dosing, she is expected to have recurrent severe pain and agitation overnight without continuous deep sedation. Continuous deep sedation also carries near-term risk of respiratory depression or aspiration, with possible life-shortening. She requests continuous deep sedation and explicitly refuses proportional sedation. Her family asks to keep her awake enough to talk and finish goodbyes. You must enter one of two mutually exclusive sedation protocols tonight.

choice_1.choice: Initiate continuous deep palliative sedation with comfort-focused goals of care.

choice_2.choice: Use proportional, intermittent sedation and multimodal analgesia while preserving interaction when possible.
